did.head: Overview of the Collection

repository.label: Repository:
repository.corpname: Archives & Special Collections at the Thomas J. Dodd Center

did.unittitle: Harry F. Brown Papers.
did.abstract: The Harry F. Brown Papers consist of 478 photographic images in various media of railroad electrification equipment along electrified main line section of the Shoreline route of the New York, New Haven & Hartford Railroad.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Harry Farnsworth Brown was born in New Haven, Connecticut, on August 17, 1886, the son of Harry Bushnell Brown and Annie Josephine Burdick. He was educated in the New Haven public schools and attended Yale University from 1903-1907, where he graduated from the Sheffield Scientific School. Following graduation he was employed by General Electric Company.

In 1910 he took a position in the Electrical Engineering Department of the New York, New Haven & Hartford Railroad. He served as a draftsman (1910), assistant engineer (1911-1922), assistant electrical engineer (1922-1946), and electrical engineer (1946-1952). When he left the railroad in 1952 he was Chief Engineer of the Engineering Department. From 1951 until his retirement he worked as a railroad consultant with Westinghouse International Co., and Gibbs & Hill in New York, New York.
Harry F. Brown married Grace A. Durham on October 11, 1911. They had six children. He was a lifelong member of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers. He died on August 11, 1980.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The Harry F. Brown papers are composed of 478 images on glass plate negatives, photographic prints, flexible negatives, 35mm film, and 35mm mounted slides. The majority of the images were taken between 1908 and 1933, with a few from 1959 and 1964. Most of the images contain railroad electrification equipment, and specifically anchor bridges and catenary along the shoreline route of the New York, New Haven & Hartford Railroad. Precisely numbered anchor bridges with exact locations appear in the photographic prints and the 35mm slides.

There are also groups of other types of images within the collection. The flexible negatives contain interior and exterior images of the power plants at Cos Cob, Connecticut and New Haven, Connecticut, as well as at Nantasket, Massachusetts. Both the glass plate negatives and the flexible negatives depict the construction of catenary. The flexible images show the Milford Bridge under construction. The 35mm slides contain a series of images of the wreck of the Federal in Bridgeport, Connecticut, in July 1955, as well as images of multiple unit passenger cars. Finally, the slides also contain images of equipment sold to the New York, New Haven & Hartford Railroad by Goodrum Substation near Porter, Indiana.

The collection includes several noteworthy images. The glass plate negatives include an image of a model of an electrification system and an electrified railroad car on a table. The photographic prints contain two images of a fire on the railroad tracks. Finally, there are a few images throughout the collection of catenary wires being built by workmen with horses and buggies.
Special thanks to Michael Ribuffo of East Northport, New York, for his valuable assistance in revising and refining the descriptions of several of the images in 2004.

arrangement.head: Organization
arrangement.p: Series I: Glass plate negatives (n.d, 1916-1917, 1921-1922) includes 9 inch x 7 inch and 4 inch x 4.5 inch negatives of both outdoor and indoor railroad electrification equipment in locations that include New Rochelle, New York, Bridgeport, Connecticut and New Haven, Connecticut. Examples of electrification equipment include, anchor bridges, catenary wires, drawbridge catenaries, right of ways, switch generators, telephone switchboards, transformers, and triangular catenaries.

Series II: Photographic prints (Black and White) (n.d., 1930, 1931) includes 5 inch x 4 inch and 3.5 inch x 4.5 inch prints of railroad electrification equipment. Examples of equipment include anchor bridges on both the Harlem River Branch and the Main Line, catenary wires, railroad signals, transformers, and triangular catenary wires. Images were taken in the Bronx, New York, Oak Point, New York and Port Chester, New York. Also included are Bridgeport,Connecticut, Cedar Hill,Connecticut, Cos Cob,Connecticut, Darien, Connecticut, Devon,Connecticut, Greens Farms, Connecticut, Greenwich, Connecticut, New Haven, Connecticut, Sound Beach, Connecticut, South Norwalk, Connecticut, Stamford, Connecticut and Westport, Connecticut.

Series III: Flexible negatives (n.d., 1908, 1912-1914, 1919-1921, 1930-1931, 1933) includes 9 inch x 7 inch saftey negatives, and 4.5 inch x 3.5 inch nitrate negatives of railroad electrification equipment. Images of the Cos Cob, Connecticut power plant, New Haven, Connecticut heat plant, and the Nantasket, Massachusetts power station are included among images of catenary construction and the construction of the Milford Bridge in Milford, Connecticut. Also included are images of equipment, such as anchor bridges, catenaries, circuit breakers, electric switch generators, lightening arresters, right of ways, rotaries, signal stations, switchboards, and triangular catenary wires. Images were taken at locations that include, Cos Cob, Connecticut, New Haven, Connecticut, and South Norwich, Connecticut; Nantasket, Massachusetts; and Porter, Indiana.
Series IV: 35mm developed film (n.d.) includes two rolls of black and white film with images of electrification equipment, including anchor bridges, catenary wires railroad bridges, and transformers.

Series V: 35mm mounted slides (n.d., 1959, 1964) includes black and white and color images of railroad electrification equipment and a series of images of an unidentified train wreck. Electrification equipment images include anchor bridges on both the Harlem River Branch and the Main Line, busses, catenary wires, multiple unit passenger cars, pantographs, railroad traffic lights, signal towers, signal transfers, transformers, and triangular catenaries. The images were taken in locations that include, New Rochelle, New York; and Bridgeport, Connecticut, Danbury, Connecticut, and Stamford, Connecticut.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Archives & Special Collections has a substantial collection of materials pertaining to New England railroads. See especially the New York, New Haven & Hartford Railroad Records and related collections. For detailed information on these collections please contact the curator or ask at the reference desk.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged by format, size and photographer's identification number.

controlaccess.head: Index Terms
controlaccess.p: This record series is indexed under the following controlled access subject terms.

controlaccess.head: Organizations:
controlaccess.corpname: New York, New Haven & Hartford Railroad

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: There are no access restrictions on this collection.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use
userestrict.p: Permission to publish from these Papers must be obtained in writing from both the University of Connecticut Libraries and the owner(s) of the copyright.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Item description, #:#], Harry F. Brown Papers. Archives & Special Collections at the Thomas J. Dodd Research Center, University of Connecticut Libraries.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: The collection was donated by Diane Brown in September 2002.

did.unittitle: Series I: Glass Plate Negatives, n.d., 1916-1917, 1921-1922
Subseries A: 9 inch X 7 inch, n.d., 1921-1922
Catenary wire and anchor brige stretching over railroad track, n.d.
Generators at the Cos Cob Power Plant, Cos Cob, Connecticut, n.d.
Transformers at the Cos Cob Power Plant, Cos Cob, Connecticut, n.d.
22 KV oil circuit-breakers in switch house, n.d.
Workmen building an anchor bridge for catenary wires, including twelve workmen watching a crane lift a piece of the anchor bridge and New York, New Haven & Hartford Railroad car 75953, n.d.

Workmen building an anchor bridge for catenary wires. Twelve men watch as a crane lifts a piece of the anchor bridge, which holds another workman. New York, New Haven & Hartford Railroad car 75953 is also included in the image, n.d.
Sweeping view of partically constructed catenary bridges. Towers are in place but bridges are not yet installed, east of Stamford, Connecticut, ca. 1913

Anchor bridge over a railroad track carrying catenary wires. Debris lies next to the track and two men stand on the track in the right bottom corner of the image, New Rochelle Junction, New York, n.d.
Anchor bridge over a railroad track with a man bending over in the left bottom corner of the image, New Rochelle Junction, New York, n.d.
Signal station 12 (SS12) at entrance to Westchester Yard, Harlem River Branch, ca. 1909
Anchor bridge with catenary wires, Harlem River Branch, n.d.
View looking south of Signal Station tower 8 and junction of 4-track New York, Westchester & Boston Railway with 6-track Harlem River Branch of the New York, New Haven & Hartford Railroad, ca. 1912
View looking north of Signal Station tower 8 and junction of 4-track New York, Westchester & Boston Railway with 6-track Harlem River Branch of the New York, New Haven & Hartford Railroad, ca. 1912
Anchor bridge carrying catenary wires over railroad tracks. On the right side of the image a train approaches. A man stands on the right side of the railroad tracks, n.d.

An anchor bridge carrying catenary wires over railroad tracks. A Boston and Maine Railroad train with four visible cars, the most visible of which is car number 47427, stands on the left side of the image, n.d.

Anchor bridge carrying catenary wires over a railroad track. Small railroad buildings stand on each side of the track. A bridge stands in the background. Several anchor bridges are visible in the background, n.d.
Anchor bridge carrying catenary wires over railroad tracks. A bridge stands behind the anchor bridge and a large building stands to the left above the railroad tracks, n.d.
New York, Westchester & Boston Railway signal station at unknown location, possibly Pelham Parkway, n.d.

Model of an electrified train car and an electrification system stretched across three tables. The surrounding room contains plaques above a black board advertising possible lectures relating to the electrification of the railroad, n.d.
Drawbridge catenary over railroad tracks. A small railroad building stands on the left side of the tracks in the background, n.d.
Another view of a drawbridge catenary over railroad tracks, n.d.
Anchor bridge 633 at Signal Station 53, Greens Farms, Connecticut, n.d.
Catenary bridge 634 connected to switch house at Signal Station 53, Greens Farms, Connecticut, n.d.

Between South Mount Vernon, New York, and New Rochelle, New York, one post of anchor bridge G 34 connects to a small shed on the side of the railroad tracks. In the background stands a house and farm buildings, n.d.
A telephone switchboard mounted on a brick wall, n.d.
A telephone switchboard connected to a large wall of equipment on the bottom floor of a two-story room, n.d.
Unknown items, possibly sections of railroad ties, n.d.

Transformers at West Farms, New Yorklocated at the junction of the Harlem River division of the New York, New Haven & Hartford Railroad and the Westchester & Boston Railroad, at 174th Street in the Bronx. "Feeder" cables to West Farms from the Sherman Creek (201st Street in Manhattan) generating plant terminated at tranformers located on an out-door platform, one such transformer appearing in the photo. , n.d.
Electrical wires attached to the underside of a bridge. A door leads into the stone wall of the bridge., n.d.
Electrical wires attched to the bottom side of a bridge, n.d.
Signal Station 78 in cut just east of New Haven, Connecticut, station, n.d.

An outside wall of a two-story building, the bottom story of which is brick and the top of which is wood. The window in the bottom story is boarded up. Another building is in the background on the left side of the image, n.d.
An unidentified roundhouse; railroad track terminates in the bottom right corner, n.d.
Another view of the same roundhouse wall, n.d.
A view of a different wall on the roundhouse. This section of the building is more square. A pile of blocks are on the ground in front of the building, n.d.
Another view of the square section of the roundhouse, n.d.
Electrical switch generator. This glass plate negative is broken and has been taped together by the previous owner, 1921
Electrical switch generator, 1921
A section of an electrical switch generator's equipment, 1921
Another view of electrical switch generator equipment, 1921
A different view of electrical switch generator equipment, 1921

Electrical right of way between New Haven, Connecticut and Bridgeport Connecticut. The image includes buildings lining the railroad track on both sides as well as anchor bridges and catenary wires, 1922
View of the right of way between New Haven, Connecticut and Bridgeport, Connecticut, 1922
Tracks curving around a building, possibly behind the roundhouse in the railroad yard in New Haven, Connecticut, 1922
In the cut west of the Mount Vernon, New York, railroad station, n.d.
In the cut west of the Mount Vernon, New York, railroad station, n.d.
Switch gear, n.d.

Electric right of way. The image includes railroad tracks and multiple bridges that run parallel to and cross over them, n.d.
Electric right of way. The image includes railroad tracks, an anchor bridge, and buildings that stand parallel to and above the tracks, n.d.
Electric right of way in an unknown town. Railroad tracks run near small business buildings and a street, on which is a horse, carriage, and a person walking, n.d.
Providence, Warren & Bristol section electrified tracks at Providence, Rhode Island, terminal and tunnel through College Hill to East Providence, n.d.
Providence, Warren & Bristol section electrified tracks at Providence, Rhode Island, terminal and tunnel through College Hill to East Providence, n.d.

Four men working on railroad tracks with an anchor bridge above their heads. A railroad car is on the tracks in the background on the right and a small railroad building is on the left of the tracks next to the workmen, June 6, 1916
A view of a triangular catenary over a railroad track including a railroad car, Stamford, Connecticut, June 6, 1916
An image including a railroad bridge that spans a large body of water and a drawbridge catenary, June 6, 1916
Triangle catenary over a railroad track, June 29, 1916
A railroad right of way that appears to lead towards a building that is under construction. There are nine workman on the ground in front of the building and on its roof, n.d.
A railroad right of way with four people standing on the tracks, possibly on the east end of the New Haven, Connecticut, station, February, 1917
Series II: Photographic Prints (Black & White), n.d., 1930, 1931
Subseries A: 3.5 inch X 4.5 inch,1930, 1931

Railroad yard in New York state looking west. Three anchor bridges, including 2H on the Harlem River Branch, and several catenaries are visible, as well as one railroad car on the far left side and two in the right background,June, 1931
Railroad signals in Oak Point, New York, looking east. Catenary wires and anchor bridges, including 41H on the Harlem River Branch, are included,December, 1930

Railroad tracks in Oak Point, New York, (Bungay Street), looking west. A signal station is on the left and in the center are catenary wires and anchor bridges, including 42H on the Harlem River Branch,December 1930

Transformer yard in Oak Point, New York, (Bungay Street) looking east. This is the same location as the previous photo (61) and contains the same signal station as well as anchor bridge 42H on the Harlem River Branch,December 1930
Anchor bridge 58H on the Harlem River Branch with electrical equipment and catenary wires looking west in Oak Point, New York,December 1930

Anchor bridge 58H on the Harlem River Branch with electrical equipment and catenary wires looking east in Oak Point, New York. This image was taken in the same location as the previous photo (63),December 1930
Transformer yard in Oak Point, New York, looking east. This photo was taken in the same location as the previous two photos (63 and 64),December 1930
South half of a transformer yard in Oak Point, New York, looking west. This photo was also taken in the same location as photos 63-65,December 1930
View looking west from anchor bridge 245 at Signal Station 27 (Byram multiple-unit car yard) toward the Life Savers factory in Port Chester, New York, April 1931
View looking east from anchor bridge 245 toward interlocking tower Signal Station 27, controlling entrance to Byram multiple-unit car yard, in Port Chester, New York, April 1931
Anchor bridge 296 in Greenwich, Connecticut, looking west. Transformers are on the anchor bridge and a railroad car is on the track,May 1931

Transformers at anchor bridge 296, located at interlocking tower Signal Station 28, east of Greenwich, Connecticut, station. This photo was taken in the same location as the previous photo (69),May 1931
Transformers at anchor bridge 296 located at interlocking tower signal station 28 east of the Greenwich, Connecticut, station, May 1931

Anchor bridge 310 in Cos Cob, Connecticut (power station) looking east. Transformers sit on the anchor bridge and connect to catenary wires. A signal station is on the right side of the track. This image was taken in the same location as the previous photo (71),May 1931
Sound Beach, Connecticut, anchor bridge 345 looking east. Transformers sit on the anchor bridge and connect to catenaries,May 1931
Stamford, Connecticut (New Canaan, Connecticut bridge) anchor bridge 374 looking west. Transformers sit on the anchor bridge and a signal station is on the left of the railroad tracks,April 1931

Stamford, Connecticut (New Canaan, Connecticut bridge) anchor bridge 374 looking east. Transformers sit on an anchor bridge and connect to catenary wires. A signal station is on the right side of the railroad tracks. Three trains are visible in the background. One man is on the left side of the tracks. This image was taken in the same location as the previous photo (74),April 1931
Interlocking tower Signal Station 40, in service, with Darien, Connecticut, freight house in background. Includes view of anchor bridge 465 looking west,April 1931

Darien, Connecticut, anchor bridge 465 looking east. Signal station 10 is on the right of the railroad tracks. There is another railroad building with a platform on the left side of the railroad tracks. A railroad car is in the background. One man stands on the tracks and three men stand next to the signal station. This image was taken in the same location as the previous photo (76),April 1931

South Norwalk, Connecticut (Danbury, Connecticut bridge) anchor bridge 524 looking west. Transformers sit on the anchor bridge and connect to catenary wires. A small railroad shed sits on the left side of the track near the anchor bridge,April 1931

South Norwalk, Connecticut (Danbury, Connecticut bridge) anchor bridge 524 looking east. Transformers sit on the anchor bridge and connect to catenary wires. Non-railroad buildings crowd around both sides of the track. This image was taken in the same location as the previous photo (78). This image has been reversed in the print,April 1931
Greens Farms, Connecticut 633 anchor bridge looking east. Transformers sit on top of the anchor bridge and connect to catenary wires. A signal station stands to the left of the tracks,May 1931

Anchor bridge 736 by Burr Road in Bridgeport, Connecticut, looking east. Transformers sit on the anchor bridge and connect to catenary wires. A man stands on the tracks with a railroad car behind him,April 1931
Anchor bridge 776 in Bridgeport, Connecticut, looking east. Shows Signal Station 62 "puzzle" switches at station. A caboose is in the center of the photo,April 1931

Anchor bridge 803 in Bridgeport, Connecticut (Central Avenue) looking west. Transformers connected to catenary wires sit on the anchor bridge. Industrial buildings are visible in the background on both sides of the railroad tracks,April 1931

Anchor bridge 803 in Bridgeport, Connecticut (Central Avenue)looking east. A motor vehicle bridge is behind the anchor bridge and crosses the expanse of the tracks. This image was taken in the same location as the previous photo (83),April 1931
Anchor bridge 814 in Bridgeport, Connecticut (Bishop Avenue) looking west,April 1931

Anchor bridge 814 in Bridgeport, Connecticut (Bishop Avenue) looking east. Transformers sit on the anchor bridge and connect to catenary wires. To the left of the railroad tracks is a signal station. This image was taken in the same location as the previous photo (85),April 1931
Signal in Devon, Connecticut, looking east. A signal station stands to the left of the railroad tracks. Anchor bridge 864 is included,April 1931
Anchor bridge 867 in Devon, Connecticut, looking east. In the distance a man is walking by the far left track,April 1931

Catenary bridge 1080 displaying horn gap switches looking west in New Haven, Connecticut (Fair Street). The image focuses on the bridge from a height equal to the top portion of the bridge. The catenary wires can be seen in great detail,April 1931

New Haven, Connecticut, anchor bridge 1104 (Mill River Junction) looking east. Catenary wires emerging from the top left corner of the photo connect to transformers on top of the anchor bridge. A signal station is on the right of the tracks,April 1931

Ceder Hill, Connecticut, anchor bridge 1117 (near New Haven) looking west. A motor vehicle bridge crosses the railroad tracks just behind the anchor bridge. The tracks split into two different ground levels, the higher of which is on the right side of the photo. A fire seems to be burning on the higher section of the tracks and emenating smoke in the dirt to the left of the track,April 1931

Anchor bridge 1117 in Ceder Hill, Connecticut (near New Haven) looking east. Smoke from a fire burning in the center of the tracks is in the background. A wall lines the lower section of the tracks on the right side of the photo. On the left side of the tracks stands a signal station. This image was taken in the same location as the previous photo (91),April 1931
Bridgeport, Connecticut, River Crossing looking east. A very tall catenary bridge is in focus in the center of the image,April 1931

Devon, Connecticut, river crossing looking north. The river water is in the foreground. Three tall catenary bridges along with the railroad track bridges span the center ground of the image horizontally,April 1931
Devon, Connecticut, river crossing looking east. This photo has a view from the railroad tracks looking through the bridges,April 1931
South Norwalk, Connecticut, river crossing looking east. A tall catenary bridge is the focus of the image. Industrial buildings are visible on the left side of the image,April 1931
South Norwalk, Connecticut, westerly high tower, power supply for the drawbridge catenary. The image is a close-up view of the tower metalwork,April 1931
Westport, Connecticut, river crossing looking east. The tall catenary bridge is in central focus. To the left and right stand railroad platforms,April 1931

Bronx, New York, river crossing towers. On the left side of the track stands a small railroad building. One person stands on the left railroad track next to the building. A railroad bridge stands behind the catenary tower,June 1931
Subseries B: 5 inch X 4 inch,n.d.

Anchor bridge under construction in an unknown location. Four men work on the top of the anchor bridge, two men stand on the tracks to the left of the construction, four men stand to the right on the tracks, and six people stand in a group on the side walk that runs alongside the left track,n.d.

View shows crew on an early wire train erecting messenger wires for compound catenary. Appears to be on the 4-track main line east of Stamford, Connecticut, but may be Harlem River Branch. Two men stand on the top of the anchor bridge, two stand on top of a construction car, two stand on a flatbed car, five stand on the track, and one operates a crane car, [ca. 1913]
Anchor bridge in an unknown location with triangular catenary wires in focus over railroad tracks,n.d.
Anchor bridge 886 between Devon, Connecticut, and Woodmont, Connecticut, with catenary wires in focus,n.d.
Anchor bridge in an unknown location with transformers connected to triangular catenary,n.d.
Subseries C: 7 inch X 5 inch,n.d.
Anchor bridge with catenary in an unknown location,n.d.
Anchor bridge with triangular catenary in an unknown location. The railroad tracks cut through rocky terrain with a residential area to the right of the tracks,n.d.
Subseries A: 9 inch X 7 inch, 1921, 1930, 1933
Electrical switch generator inside a brick room. This is possibly a nitrate negative,1921
Cos Cob, Connecticut, power plant. The image contains a view from above of eight large electrical machines spanning the length of a large concrete room,1930
Cos Cob, Connecticut, power plant, from a different view. This image contains a two-story high round piece of machinery that has a walkway surrounding it, 1930
Cos Cob, Connecticut, power plant, back-bus structure row of oil circuit-breakers, 1930
Cos Cob, Connecticut, power plant, 22 KV circuit-breakers in switch house, 1930
Cos Cob, Connecticut, power plant, 22 KV bus over traction-power transformers, 1930
Cos Cob, Connecticut, power plant, local service transformers, 1930
Cos Cob, Connecticut, power plant, a view from the outside of the building,1930
Cos Cob, Connecticut, power plant. A view of two large cement pools of water outside the building,1930
Cos Cob, Connecticut, power plant, a wide view of the building, including a New York, New Haven & Hartford Railroad car,1930
View look west toward Cos Cob Power Plant from across Mianus River. Shows hopper car unloading track, coal conveyor and storage pile, coal barge pierand coal leg for unloading coal barges, 1930
Another view of the Cos Cob, Connecticut power plant from across the Mianus River. In the right side of the image a train is passing by the plant,1930
Another view of the Cos Cob, Connecticut, power plant from across the Mianus River,1930
Another inside view of the Cos Cob, Connecticut, power plant. This is another image of the two-story large machinery with the circular walkway surrounding it,1930
Another view of outdoor concrete water pools at the Cos Cob, Connecticut, power plant,1930
Another wide view from across the railroad track of the Cos Cob, Connecticut, power plant,1930
A different exposure of the view from across the railroad track of the Cos Cob, Connecticut, power plant,1930
New Haven, Connecticut, heat plant. The image is taken from a distance and includes railroad tracks that cross in front of the building,1930
Another view of the New Haven, Connecticut, heat plant. The image is taken from a distance and includes railroad tracks that cross in front of the building,1930
New Haven, Connecticut, heat plant, a closer view of the building and its smoke stacks,1930
An interior view of the New Haven, Connecticut, heat plant. The image includes multiple banks of machinery filling a three-story room,1930
A closeup view of banks of machinery inside the New Haven, Connecticut, power plant,1930

OB installation E cut, possibly in New Haven, Connecticut. The image contains a close-up view of an anchor bridge crossing railroad tracks with signal station 78 in cut east of the New Haven station,July 28, 1933
OB installation E cut, possibly in New Haven, Connecticut. This image is a closer view of the anchor bridge and includes a train passing through on the left of the image,July 28, 1933
Subseries B: 4.5 inch X 3.5 inch, nitrate negatives, n.d., 1908, 1912-1914, 1919-1920, 1931
View looking east from Stamford, Connecticut, station. Note baggage cars stored at right, in yard off Atlantic and Manhattan Streets, 1908
Stamford, Connecticut to Cos Cob, Connecticut, track. The image includes a view of a railroad bridge as well as of triangular catenary wires connected to anchor bridges that hold transformers,1908
Unknown location between Stamford, Connecticut, and New Rochelle, New York,February 2, 1912
New Haven, Connecticut, catenary and right of way,February 2, 1912
View of possibly the Westchester yard, Harlem River Branch,February 2, 1912
View of possibly the Westchester yard, Harlem River Branch, n.d.
View of possibly the Westchester yard, Harlem River Branch. The image was taken from the top of a railroad car, n.d.
Catenary and anchor bridge over a railroad track. Fences are on either side of the railroad track,n.d.

View of freight cars and catenary construction in Mount Vernon, New York, freight yard. There is a New York, Westchester & Boston Railway viaduct in the background [Note: the New York, Westchester & Boston Railway was a NHRR subsidiary in Westchester county with 2-track branches that ran from Port Chester, New York, and White Plains, New York, to a junction at Columbus Avenue in Mount Vernon, New York. It ran as 4 tracks to a connection with the Harlem River Branch (SS8) in the Bronx, terminating at Harlem River. All built as a high-capacity railroad with 11,000 volt AC electrification for multiple unit car operation. It opened 1912, was abandoned in 1937 and scrapped during World War II],[ca. 1920]
Horses pulling a cart under a catenary. A workman stands on a cart in front of the horses,n.d.
Catenary wires and anchor bridges in an unknown location,n.d.
Two men standing by a railroad track near an anchor bridge in an unknown location. Trains sit on railroad tracks behind the men,n.d.
Catenary wires above a railroad yard in an unknown location,n.d.
Catenary wires above a railroad track in an unknown location. A train sits on the track and stretches into the background,n.d.

View showing catenary at end of car float apron at Oak Point [Note: a carfloat is the bridge-like part of a "float bridge"; the pier structure that transfers cars onto carfloats (railroad car barges) for movement between rail/marine terminals. There were many types of float bridges, having the common characteristic of providing a movable, hinged apron that made up for variations in the height of the carfloat deck relative to the yard tracks due to tidal changes, as well as the twisting and vertical movement of the carfloat itself as strings of heavy freight cars (as many as 22 per float) were added or removed], n.d.
View showing catenary at end of carfloat apron at Oak Point, n.d.
Catenary wires and anchor bridges over a railroad track in an unknown location,n.d.
Views showing compound catenary at Pelham Bay drawbridge on Harlem River Branch. Note high transmission towers at drawbridge to raise power feeders above sailing ship masts, n.d.
View looking east toward anchor bridge 245 and interlocking tower SS27 at entrance to Byram multiple unit car yard, n.d.
View looking east toward Byram, Connecticut, from catenary bridge 262 in Port Chester, New York, n.d.
An anchor bridge holding transformers near an industrial area in an unknown location,n.d.

View looking east showing signal tower SS25 at catenary bridge 167 between Mamaroneck, New York, and Rye, New York. [There is damage on the top left and bottom right corners. The negative is brittle and shows some shrinking], n.d.

View of wire train on 4-track main line east of Stamford, Connecticut, erecting messenger wires for compound catenary. The image includes a New York, New Haven & Hartford Railroad work car with a crane and several workmen standing around it,April 4, 1913
View of wire train on 4-track main line east of Stamford, Connecticut, erecting messenger wires for compound catenary,April 4, 1913
View of wire train on 4-track main line east of Stamford, Connecticut, erecting messenger wires for compound catenary. This view is taken from behind the platform on which the men work,April 4, 1913

View of wire train on 4-track main line east of Stamford, Connecticut, erecting messenger wires for compound catenary. This image contains an empty railroad track and low hanging catenary wires on the right side of the track, April 4, 1913

View of wire train on 4-track main line east of Stamford, Connecticut, erecting messenger wires for compound catenary. The image contains the empty railroad track and low hanging catenary wires and is taken from the opposite direction, April 4, 1913

View of wire train on 4-track main line east of Stamford, Connecticut, erecting messenger wires for compound catenary. The worktrain in this image holds a spool that is distributing catenary wire outwards, April 4, 1913
View of wire train on 4-track main line east of Stamford, Connecticut, erecting messenger wires for compound catenary, September 26, 1913
Support for a future anchor bridge on the New Haven, Connecticut, right of way. The cement support is awaiting the construction of the anchor bridge,September 26, 1913
A cement support at the foot of an anchor bridge on a New Haven, Connecticut, right of way, September 26, 1913
Anchor bridges on a New Haven, Connecticut, right of way,September 26, 1913
The wheels of a train, December 3, 1913

View during construction of high transmission tower, used at drawbridges to raise power feeders above sailing ship masts. A crane lifts a beam into the air, three men stand on the central crossing of the anchor bridge, and four men stand under the anchor bridge on the railroad track, December 5, 1913
New Haven, Connecticut, right of way and anchor bridge with transformers,December 5, 1913
Bridgeport, Connecticut, anchor bridge,April 13, 1914
South Norwalk, Connecticut anchor bridge and catenary wires,April 13, 1914

View looking south toward Dock Yark in South Norwalk, Connecticut. [The top left corner of this negative is ripped and has been taped back to the rest of the negative with scotch tape on the non-emulsion side], April 13, 1914

View looking north over train on Danbury Branch, adjacent to Dock Yard in South Norwalk, Connecticut. [The top right corner of this negative has been ripped and has been held together to the rest of the negative with scotch tape on the edge of the emulsion side], April 13, 1914

A railroad track with electrical poles running alongside in an unknown location. The negative has an oblong discoloration in its top left corner,August 1920

A 300KW rotary with a DC end at Goodrum Substation near Porter, Indiana. The image is one of a group of images of equipment that the New York, New Haven & Hartford Railroad bought for Nantasket, Massachusetts,August 14, 1920

Installing freight lead new Cedar Hill Yard, east of New Haven, Connecticut. The image includes several men working down the length of the track,September 19, 1920

Erection of the Milford Bridge over the New York, New Haven & Hartford Railroad in Milford, Connecticut,1931

Erection of the Milford Bridge over the New York, New Haven & Hartford Railroad in Milford, Connecticut. A crane lifts a part of the bridge over the heads of four people, one of which may be a child. This negative is discolored in the center,1931

Erection of the Milford Bridge over the New York, New Haven & Hartford Railroad in Milford, Connecticut. A different view of a crane lifting a portion of the bridge over the heads of three people. A large discoloration crosses half the negative,1931
Erection of the Milford Bridge over the New York, New Haven & Hartford Railroad in Milford, Connecticut, a view from farther away. This negative has a stain over the bottom left corner,1931
Erection of the Milford Bridge over the New York, New Haven & Hartford Railroad in Milford, Connecticut in 1931, a different view,1931
Series IV: 35mm Developed Film, ca. 1959

It appears that all of the images on this roll, like 7:191, were taken on the same day, during a trip from Oak Point to Greenwich, to document facilities slated for abandonment. Roll 7:190 primarily shows towers SS27 and Byram multiple unit car yard subsequent to its closing in 1958 and just prior to the 1959 abandonment of Byram yard and removal of interlocking tower SS27, its main line switches, all yard catenary and bridges, and most yard tracks, ca. 1959
Various views in area of New Rochelle Junction, New York, ca. 1959
View of transformers at interlocking tower SS26 in Rye, New York, ca. 1959
View looking east from base of interlocking tower SS27 toward entrance of Byram multiple unit car yard, ca. 1959
View looking east toward anchor bridge 245 and interlocking tower SS27 at entrance to Byram multiple unit car yard, ca. 1959
View looking west from anchor bridge 245 at SS27 (Byram multiple unit car yard) toward Life Savers factory in Port Chester, New York, ca. 1959
Wide views toward interlocking tower SS27 and Byram multiple unit car yard from opposite (north) side of mainline, ca. 1959
View toward interlocking tower SS27 from opposite (north) side of mainline with westbound EP-4 and train passing, ca. 1959
Close-in view of interlocking tower SS27 and transformers from opposite (north) side of mainline, ca. 1959

Ground level view of track switches looking toward Byram Yard throat from base of SS27 [Note: a throat is the point where the multiple tracks in a yard fan out through a series of track switches - literally the mouth (entrance/exit) of the yard. It is quite pronounced at the Byram yard, where about 8-10 MU storage tracks and a couple of freight sidings all come together to connect with the main line in front of tower SS27], ca. 1959
View of transformers at SS27 looking down from second floor of interlocking tower, ca. 1959
High-level views toward Byram multiple unit car yard from tower SS27, showing layout of yard and freight sidings, ca. 1959
Views taken at SS28 and Greenwich, Connecticut, railroad station, ca. 1959
This roll consists of various scenes on the Harlem River Branch, possibly taken in connection with a NHRR study (ca. 1959) proposing the abandonment and removal of certain main line tracks, ca. 1959
Various views of track and catenary structures between Oak Point and New Rochelle Junction on Harlem River Branch, ca. 1959

Series V: 35mm Mounted Slides, consisting primarily of scenes along the electrified single-track Danbury Branch, and views of catenary modifications and other construction at New Rochelle Junction in connection with the Interstate 95 highway overpass construction, n.d., 1959, 1964
Subseries A: Black & White, n.d.

[Note: Images 280 through 338 are various scenes of a station, catenary structures, a wire train, new foundations, and other construction in the vicinity of New Rochelle Junction, all in connection with the Interstate 95 highway overpass construction.]

A view of converging railroad tracks with a signal tower to their left. Several anchor bridges are in view, one of which is holding transfomers. Catenary run above the tracks along the anchor bridges,n.d.
A closer view of a signal tower next to railroad tracks. Several anchor bridges are crossing the tracks, one of which holds several transformers. Catenary are running above the tracks,n.d.
A view of anchor bridge 65 on the Main Line looking east near New Rochelle, New York. The anchor bridge stands in front of a bridge that crosses the tracks. Catenary run under the bridge,n.d.
A view of anchor bridge 63 on the Main Line looking west in New Rochelle, New York. A signal tower stands to the left of the railroad tracks and the catenary are in clear view above the tracks,n.d.

[Note: Images 375 through 469 are varoius view of the right-of-way, catenary structures, wire train repairing damaged catenary, and wrecked locomotive and cars in the Bridgeport, Connecticut, area following the Federal wreck in July 1955]

Four railroad tracks in an industrail area with a body of water in the distance. In the left side of the image a train rounds a curve, July 1955
Four railroad tracks under an anchor bridge with A-frame posts and multiple wire equipment on the crossing post. A sign by the base of the left post reads either "4284" or "4234", July 1955
Four railroad tracks under multiple anchor bridges that carry multiple wire equipment on the crossing posts. A five car train moves away down the second track from the left, July 1955
Four railroad tracks under multiple anchor bridges that hold equipment. Multiple wires connect to the crossing post, July 1955
Four railroad tracks under multiple anchor bridges, which have catenary wires along their crossing posts and wires stretching diagonally from the side posts to the ground beside them,July 1955
A close-up of the crossing post and left post of an anchor bridge with its catenary wires over four railroad tracks,July 1955

At least seven, possibly eight, railroad tracks with wide and elaborate anchor bridges stretching across them. Two men stand near the right post of the closest anchor bridge to the viewer and freight train cars stand on the tracks to the left,July 1955

Anchor bridges with very tall extension posts above each side post that raise the wires far above the tracks. On the left of the four tracks is a cage-like grouping of electrical equipment. The side of a railroad bridge is in the bottom right corner of the image,July 1955

A complex group of wires attached to multiple anchor bridges, including the catenary wires above the four railroad tracks, wires following along the sides of the tracks, and wires stretching diagonally from the side posts of the anchor bridges to the ground,July 1955

Another image of a complex grouping of wires attached to multiple anchor bridges, including catenary wires above the railroad tracks, wires following along the sides of the tracks, and wires stretching diagonally from the side posts of the anchor bridges to the ground beside them,July 1955
An anchor bridge holding catenary and other wires to the right of a railroad bridge's side, July 1955
Catenary wires stretching over four railroad tracks and multiple anchor bridges in an industrial area, July 1955
Catenary and other wires connected to anchor bridges with side posts extending high above the crossing post that carry wires far above the tracks, July 1955
Catenary over anchor bridges that carry other types of wires on extended posts both on the left side post and on the right side of the crossing post,July 1955
Another view of anchor bridges that have extra equipment to hold other wires in addition to catenary wires,July 1955
Another view of anchor bridges that have extra equipment to hold other wires in addition to catenary in an industrial area,July 1955
Another view of anchor bridges that have extra equipment to hold other wires in addition to catenary in an industrial area,July 1955
A view of catenary and other wires following a curve in the railroad tracks on the anchor bridges that have extra equipment above,July 1955
Catenary and other wires following a curve in the railroad track on two pieces of extra equipment centered on the crossing post of each anchor bridge,July 1955
Catenary and other wires following a curve in the railroad track on two pieces of extra equipment centered on the crossing post of each anchor bridge,July 1955
Catenary and other wires following a curve in the railroad track on two pieces of extra equipment centered on the crossing post of each anchor bridge,July 1955
Catenary and other wires following a curve in the railroad track on two pieces of extra equipment centered on the crossing post of each anchor bridge,July 1955
Catenary and other wires following a curve in the railroad track on two pieces of extra equipment centered on the crossing post of each anchor bridge,July 1955
Catenary and other wires following a curve in the railroad track on two pieces of extra equipment centered on the crossing post of each anchor bridge,July 1955
An anchor bridge with A-frame side posts and two pieces of extra equipment centered on the crossing post for catenary and other wires,July 1955
A bar attached to the catenary wires and spanning the width of all four railroad tracks but having no support from the ground, July 1955
Catenary and other wires following a curve in the railroad tracks on two pieces of equipment centered on the crossing post of each anchor bridge,July 1955
Catenary and other wires following a curve in the railroad tracks on two pieces of equipment centered on the crossing post of each anchor bridge,July 1955
Catenary and other wires following a curve in the railroad tracks on two pieces of equipment centered on the crossing post of each anchor bridge,July 1955
Catenary and other wires following a curve in the railroad tracks on two pieces of equipment centered on the crossing post of each anchor bridge,July 1955
Catenary and other wires following a curve in the railroad tracks on two pieces of equipment centered on the crossing post of each anchor bridge,July 1955
Catenary and other wires following a curve in the railroad tracks on two pieces of equipment centered on the crossing post of each anchor bridge,July 1955

Catenary and other wires following a curve in the railroad track on anchor bridges. One piece of extra equipment for holding wires extends up from the right post of the anchor bridge and another rests off center to the left on the crossing post,July 1955

Catenary and other wires following a curve in the railroad track on anchor bridges. One piece of extra equipment for holding wires extends up from the right post of the anchor bridge and another rests off center to the left on the crossing post,July 1955

Catenary and other wires following a curve in the railroad track on anchor bridges. One piece of extra equipment for holding wires extends up from the right post of the anchor bridge and another rests off center to the left on the crossing post,July 1955

Catenary and other wires following a curve in the railroad track on anchor bridges. One piece of extra equipment for holding wires extends up from the right post of the anchor bridge and another rests off center to the left on the crossing post. In addition, a tall pole stands on the crossing post, raising many wires far above the anchor bridges,July 1955

An anchor bridge with two exceptinally tall poles extending up from the right post and from near the left post on the crossing post, and with a third, smaller, piece of equipment towards the center of the crossing post. All of this extra equipment carries catenary and other wires high above the anchor bridge,July 1955

An anchor bridge with two exceptinally tall poles extending up from the right post and from near the left post on the crossing post, and with a third, smaller, piece of equipment towards the center of the crossing post. All of this extra equipment carries catenary and other wires high above the anchor bridge,July 1955
A close-up view of catenary wires stretching out from the underside of an anchor bridge's crossing post,July 1955

A view of catenary and other wires connected to an anchor bridge and to two extremely tall poles on it, one extending from the right post and the other from just to the right of the left post. Also holding wires is a smaller piece of equipment near the center of the crossing post,July 1955
Catenary and other wires connected to an anchor bridge and to two tall poles extending up from the left and right posts of the anchor bridge,July 1955

A view of an anchor bridge with catenary and other wires connecting to it,to a small piece of equipment standing near the center of the crossing post, and to two tall poles extending high into the air up from the left post and from near the right post of the crossing post,July 1955

A tall triangular tower stands over the railroad tracks between many anchor bridges. Wires stretch from the top of the tower, far above the anchor bridges, and out of the image. Catenary and other wires connect to the anchor bridges and to poles extending up from their crossing posts,July 1955
Subseries B: Color, n.d., 1959, 1964
A railway yard with an oncoming train in the top left corner and a departing train in the top right corner. Buildings are in the center positioned between two large groups of railroad tracks,May 1959

A railway yard with two trains departing on the top right portion of the image. A string of railroad traffic lights and multiple electrical poles are also visible in the right portion of the slide. In the top left a group of blue railroad buildings are positioned between two groups of tracks,May 1959
An outdoors, close-up image of a wire connected to electrical equipment on a pole,April 1964
An outdoors, close-up image of a wire connected to electrical equipment on a pole,April 1964

A single railroad track next to a brick building. A metal pole extends from the roof of the building across two metal supports, like an anchor bridge. Two wires run down the center of the crossing pole and connect to electrical equipment,April 1964

A view across multiple railroad tracks near the entrance of a railroad station. Above the tracks are a complex web of electrical wires. Two cars of a passenger train are on the left side of the photo. On the right side, the back of a caboose is visible,April 1964
A view from a single railroad track entering a group of tracks. Above the tracks is a complex web of electrical wires. Also in view on the right is a stop sign for the single track,April 1964

A train entering under an anchor bridge in a wooded area. Attached to the anchor bridge from the side posts are two tall electrical poles which carry many wires. Equipment also extends down under the crossing post. Five pipes run along the left side of the railroad tracks, n.d.

New York, New Haven & Hartford Railroad looking west in Stamford, Connecticut at four o'clock in the afternoon. The image was taken at the Stamford railroad station, including both platforms, railroad traffic lights, anchor bridges, triangular catenary wires and a passenger train. At least four passengers are visible on the right platform,January 10, 1959
